titlepage.titleproper: Register of the Socialist Workers Party Records, 1928-1990
titlepage.publisher:
Hoover Institution Archives
Stanford University
Stanford, California
titlepage.p: © 1998 Hoover Institution Archives. All rights reserved.

did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.abstract: Correspondence, minutes, resolutions, theses, and internal bulletins, relating to Trotskyist and other socialist activities in Latin America, Western Europe, Iran, and elsewhere, and to interactions of the Socialist Workers Party with the Fourth International; and trial transcripts, briefs, other legal documents, and background materials, relating to the lawsuit brought by Alan Gelfand against the Socialist Workers Party in 1979. .

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: The Hoover Institution Archives only allows access to copies of audiovisual items. To listen to sound recordings or to view videos or films during your visit, please contact the Archives at least two working days before your arrival. We will then advise you of the accessibility of the material you wish to see or hear. Please note that not all audiovisual material is immediately accessible.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Socialist Workers Party Records, [Box no.], Hoover Institution Archives.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Acquired by the Hoover Institution Archives in 1992.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Materials may have been added to the collection since this finding aid was prepared. To determine if this has occurred, find the collection in Stanford University's online catalog at http://searchworks.stanford.edu/. Materials have been added to the collection if the number of boxes listed in the online catalog is larger than the number of boxes listed in this finding aid.

altformavail.head: Alternative Form Available
altformavail.p: Most of collection also available on microfilm (107 reels).

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The Socialist Workers Party had its origins in the Communist League of America, formed in 1928 by former members of the Workers (Communist) Party of America who had been expelled as followers of Leon Trotsky. The Communist League of America merged with the American Workers Party in 1934 to create the Workers Party of the United States. This organization dissolved in 1936 to allow its members to enter the Socialist Party, where they constituted a left wing. Members of the left wing, after expulsion from the Socialist Party, founded the Socialist Workers Party at the beginning of 1938.

From its outset as the Communist League of America, the Socialist Workers Party viewed itself as the American section of an international left wing of the communist movement whose outstanding leader was Leon Trotsky. This current first found organizational expression as the International Left Opposition in 1930. A belief that the program and practices of the Communist International were in need of drastic reform gradually gave way to the conviction that that organization was incorrigible and should be supplanted. The course of this progression of thought is indicated by the transformation of the International Left Opposition into the International Communist League in 1933 and then into the Movement for the Fourth International in 1936. The Fourth International was established in 1938 with the proclaimed goal of serving as the world party of socialist revolution.

World War II disrupted the workings of the Fourth International and many of its sections. A European Secretariat in exile functioned in the United States during the war. The passage in 1940 of the Voorhis Act, which required parties belonging to any international political organization to register with the United States government and provide lists of members and contributors, prompted the Socialist Workers Party to formally disaffiliate from the Fourth International. When the International resumed its operations after the war, the party maintained a close relationship with it and was recognized as a fraternal organization but never formally rejoined as its American section.

Political differences within the Fourth International resulted in a rupture in 1954. Most of the continental European sections adhered to the orientation of the International Secretariat, the International's continuing directing body. The Socialist Workers Party aligned itself with some other sections in establishing a rival International Committee. For all practical purposes Fourth International (International Secretariat) and Fourth International (International Committee) operated as separate organizations. Unity of most forces on both sides was restored in 1963, with a newly created United Secretariat as continuing directing body.

Rupture again threatened but was averted in the 1970s. The Socialist Workers Party aligned itself with a number of Latin American sections in creating a Leninist-Trotskyist Tendency (subsequently Leninist-Trotskyist Faction) within the International in 1973. This was opposed by an International Majority Tendency representing most of the European sections. The factions were dissolved in 1977.

The Socialist Workers Party found itself increasingly in disagreement with the Fourth International in the 1980s as the party ceased to define itself as Trotskyist. The Fourth International meanwhile accorded recognition to two organizations originating in splits from the party, Socialist Action and the Fourth Internationalist Tendency, as sympathizing American sections in addition to the Socialist Workers Party. The 12th World Congress of the Fourth International in 1985 was the last in which representatives of the Socialist Workers Party participated. Since the party was not formally a member of the Fourth International the question of formal withdrawal did not arise. However by the end of the decade the Socialist Workers Party had broken off all connections with the Fourth International.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Records of the Socialist Workers Party are deposited at the Wisconsin State Historical Society as well as in the Hoover Institution Archives. Those at the Wisconsin State Historical Society are concerned with domestic activities of the party, while those in the Hoover Institution Archives are concerned with its international activities and especially with its relations with the Fourth International and its predecessors.

Records in the Hoover Institution Archives are arranged in nine series, most of which call for some commentary. Fourth International Issuances, the first series, consists of official issuances, notably minutes, congress proceedings, and internal bulletins, of the Fourth International and its predecessors. Issuances of international bodies only, not national sections, are included. These are arranged by issuing bodies, which are listed in order of historical progression. Issuances lend themselves to serial arrangement and are listed in considerable detail.

The next two series, Chronological File and Geographical File, are extremely rich but much more amorphous. Correspondence between Socialist Workers Party leaders and Fourth International leaders, reports and memoranda of all descriptions, and official and unofficial documents of all sorts emanating from practically every national section are included. Materials within the two files are similar in character and many documents might with equal validity have found their way into either. Individual folders as maintained by the Socialist Workers Party and the Library of Social History (where the records were held prior to their deposit in the Hoover Institution Archives) tended to be established and assigned headings according to criteria that were either chronological or geographical. These classificatory decisions were respected and the two series were constructed by grouping folders together according to which of the two criteria they met. Arrangement of the material within each was then regularized. It is important for researchers interested in a particular geographical area to keep in mind that the Chronological File as well as the Geographical File is likely to include relevant material. An attempt has been made to annotate the Chronological File listings with indications of concentrations of material relating to specific countries, but such annotations are by no means exhaustive. Official issuances of national sections lending themselves to serial listing are generally specified. Other materials are generally not itemized, not because their importance is less but because a rigorously itemized list would be of prohibitive length.
The International Assignments File consists of correspondence and reports of Socialist Workers Party representatives abroad on international assignments, mainly during the 1970s.

The Barnes/Waters File is drawn from the papers of Jack Barnes and Mary-Alice Waters, leaders of the Socialist Workers Party and its principal representatives in dealings with the Fourth International during the 1970s and 1980s. Arranged chronologically by congresses and other meetings of the Fourth International, it is a major source for activities of the International during those decades and includes much material, especially minutes and world congress proceedings, that might otherwise have been included in the Fourth International Issuances series.

The Leninist-Trotskyist Faction File consists of internal circulated materials documenting the history of the international Leninist-Trotskyist Faction (described in the Historical Note above) during the period of its existence from 1973 to 1977.

The Gelfand vs. Smith et al. File requires special explanation. The Workers Revolutionary Party and the Workers League, Trotskyist organizations in Great Britain and the United States respectively that remained outside the Fourth International (United Secretariat), embarked in 1975 upon a series of allegations that Soviet secret police and United States Federal Bureau of Investigation penetration of the Socialist Workers Party beginning in the 1930s had turned that party into one that was police-controlled. These allegations were characterized by the Socialist Workers Party, and by a number of unaffiliated observers, as a slander campaign. Alan Gelfand, an expelled member of the Socialist Workers Party, initiated a lawsuit in 1979 against leaders of the party and leading law enforcement officials of the United States government on the basis of these allegations. The case went to trial in federal district court in 1983 and resulted in judgment against Gelfand. This series contains not only the legal records of the Socialist Workers Party defendants in the trial but also extensive background material on the allegations and their history.
Official issuances of international bodies of the Fourth International and its predecessors. Arranged by issuing body.

scopecontent.p: Records of the Socialist Workers Party's interactions with the Fourth International and its predecessors, not classified by geographical area, including correspondence, notes, memoranda, reports, proposals, theses, resolutions, declarations, statements, manifestos, appeals and circulars. Arranged chronologically.

did.unittitle: 1933. Includes correspondence of Leon Trotsky, report on Conference of Four of December 30, and material on Spain, Germany and the United States
1934. Includes correspondence of Leon Trotsky, and material on Great Britain, Belgium, France and Germany
1935. Includes correspondence of Leon Trotsky, and material on Belgium, France, Spain, the United States, and the London Bureau
1936. Includes correspondence of Leon Trotsky, and material on Spain and the United States
1937. Includes correspondence of Leon Trotsky, and material on Spain, Indochina, China, the United States, and the German group in exile
1938. Includes correspondence of Leon Trotsky, and material on Great Britain, Poland, South Africa, the United States, and the murder of Rudolf Klement
1941. Includes material on Argentina and Chile
1942. Includes material on Argentina and Europe
1944. Includes material on France, Indochina, China, and prospects for postwar Europe

1945. Includes material on Chile, Great Britain, Belgium, France, Italy, Egypt, Palestine, India/Ceylon, Australia, the Spanish group in exile in Mexico, the Goldman-Morrow group in the United States, and the Nuremberg Trials

1946. Includes material on Great Britain, Belgium, France, Austria, Germany, the Spanish group in exile in Mexico, the Goldman-Morrow group and the Workers Party in the United States, and the Nuremberg Trials

1947. Includes material on Argentina, Great Britain, France, Germany, Greece, China, Mexico and the Spanish group in exile there, the Goldman-Morrow group and the Workers Party in the United States, the Ecole Internationale des Cadres, and colonialism
1948. Includes material on Great Britain, France, Germany, Czechoslovakia, Yugoslavia, India/Ceylon, China, Japan, and the United States
1949. Includes material on Great Britain, France, Italy, Yugoslavia, Indonesia, and Mexico and the Spanish group in exile there
1950. Includes material on Italy, Germany, Yugoslavia, China, the United States, Ukrainians in exile, and the Korean War
1951. Includes material on France, the United States, and Nataliia Sedova Trotskaia in Mexico
1952. Includes material on Bolivia, Great Britain, France, and Ceylon
1953. Includes material on Great Britain, France, Germany, the United States, the Chinese group in exile, and the International Secretariat/International Committee split in the Fourth International

1954. Includes material on Canada, Bolivia, Argentina, Great Britain, Denmark, the Netherlands, France, India, Ceylon, the Chinese group in exile, and the International Secretariat/International Committee split in the Fourth International
1955. Includes material on Great Britain and France
1956. Includes material on Chile, the Soviet Union, and Bulgarians in exile

1958. Includes material on Great Britain, Spain, the youth movement in the United States, and Fourth International unity negotiations (including papers of Sherry Mangan)
1959. Includes material on Great Britain and Greece

1961. Includes material on Canada, Cuba, Jamaica, and Great Britain, and the Latin American Bureau of the Fourth International

1963. Includes material on Canada, Bolivia, Argentina, Great Britain, and reunification of the Fourth International
1964. Includes material on Canada, Mexico, Cuba, Venezuela, Bolivia, Chile, Argentina, Great Britain, and the Pablo faction split from the Fourth International
1966. Includes material on Cuba, Peru, Great Britain, France, Italy, Iran, Ceylon, and China and the Sino-Soviet dispute
1967. Includes material on Bolivia, Great Britain, France, and Greece
1968. Includes material on Cuba, Puerto Rico, Belgium, France, Czechoslovakia, and Ceylon

1969. Includes material on Mexico, Peru, Bolivia, Argentina, Great Britain, Belgium, France, Czechoslovakia, Algeria, Nigeria, India, Ceylon, China, Japan, Australia, New Zealand, the United States, and the anti-Vietnam War movement
1970. Includes material on Canada, Great Britain, and France
1971. Includes material on Great Britain and Czechoslovakia
1972. Includes material on Canada, Peru, Bolivia, Chile, Argentina, Uruguay, Great Britain, Sweden, France, Czechoslovakia, India, Sri Lanka, Australia, and the anti-Vietnam War movement
1973. Includes material on Canada, Chile, Argentina, Sweden, France, Pakistan, Hong Kong, and New Zealand
1974. Includes material on Canada, Mexico, Brazil, Great Britain, Sweden, France, Italy, Germany, India, Japan, Australia, and New Zealand
1975. Includes material on France, Portugal, and India

1976. Includes material on Argentina, Portugal, Angola, the Organizing Committee for the Reconstruction of the Fourth International, and the Leninist-Trotskyist Faction and International Majority Tendency within the Fourth International

1977. Includes material on France, Spain, the United States (Socialist Union), political prisoners in Eastern Europe, and the Bolshevik Tendency within the Fourth International, and reminiscences of Michel Pablo

1978. Includes material on El Salvador, Costa Rica, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, Bolivia, Argentina, Iceland, Ireland, Great Britain, France, Spain, Portugal, Lebanon, Vietnam, the Organizing Committee for the Reconstruction of the Fourth International, the Bolshevik Tendency, political prisoners in Eastern Europe, the women's movement, and the anti-nuclear movement
1979. Includes material on France, Iran, and splits of the Bolshevik Faction and the Leninist-Trotskyist Tendency from the Fourth International
1980. Includes material on Nicaragua, Bolivia, Afghanistan, and the Bolshevik Faction
1981. Includes material on Peru, Bolivia, and Poland

scopecontent.p: Records of the Socialist Workers Party's interactions with the Fourth International and its predecessors, classified by geographical area, including correspondence, notes, memoranda, reports, minutes, agenda, resolutions, theses, declarations, statements, circulars, and printed issuances. Arranged alphabetically by country. Other material relating to particular countries may be located in the CHRONOLOGICAL FILE

scopecontent.p: Reports to the Socialist Workers Party by party representatives with international assignments, and correspondence between the party and these representatives. Arranged alphabetically by name of representative.

Papers of Jack Barnes and Mary-Alice Waters as Socialist Workers Party representatives in interactions with the Fourth International, including correspondence, notes, reports, agenda, minutes, declarations, resolutions, appeals, theses, drafts and preparatory material. Consists largely of material documenting meetings of international bodies of the Fourth International. Arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.p: Records of the Socialist Workers Party's interactions with the Leninist-Trotskyist Faction, an international faction within the Fourth International, including correspondence, minutes, reports, and discussion documents. Consists mainly of sets of circulated internal documents.

Reports and lists of material on the history of the Fourth International at Harvard University, the Internationaal Institut voor Sociale Geschiedenis, the Bibliothèque de Documentation Internationale Contemporaine and elsewhere

did.unittitle: GELFAND VS. SMITH ET AL. FILE, 1979-1990.

scopecontent.p: Legal records and background material, relating to the legal case of Gelfand vs. Smith et al., in which Socialist Workers Party leaders were defendants, including trial and hearing transcripts, exhibits, depositions, legal motions and briefs, correspondence, internal reports, and printed matter.

Chronological file of official court documents, 1979-1989. Motions, petitions, briefs, stipulations, affidavits, proposed findings, memoranda of law, notices, orders, applications, requests, interrogatories, statements, declarations, responses, reports, and exhibits to the above
July. Plaintiff's complaint for civil rights violations
September. Includes Socialist Workers Party defendants' motion to dismiss

September. Includes federal defendants' answer to amended complaint, and Socialist Workers Party defendants' motion for summary judgment

September. Includes plaintiff's motion for additional pretrial discovery

January 17-28. Includes plaintiff's interrogatories and responses to interrogatories, and Socialist Workers Party defendants' interrogatories and motions to dismiss for lack of subject matter jurisdiction and for stay of all further proceedings
February 1-12. Includes Socialist Workers Party defendants' motion that Judge Pfaelzer disqualify herself
February 14-28. Includes plaintiff's trial brief and responses to interrogatories, and Socialist Workers Party defendants' answer to interrogatories
March. Includes Sylvia Doxsee grand jury testimony released to plaintiff
August. Includes plaintiff's interrogatories re attorneys' fees and costs
September. Includes Socialist Workers Party defendants' responses to interrogatories
February. Includes Socialist Workers Party defendants' motion for interim award of attorney's fees and costs
